Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Nanotopographical Memory Modulates Stem Cell Fate

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1511759
Yang, Yong

Conventional cell culture methods using flat, stiff plastic surfaces do not recapitulate characteristics (e.g., stiffness and nanotopography) of the extracellular matrix (ECM) with which cells interact in vivo. Therefore, cell behavior on such surfaces significantly deviate from their in vivo counterparts. There is a pressing need to incorporate the ECM characteristics into stem cell culture technologies. The goal of this research is to advance next-generation cell culture technologies by investigating nanotopographical memory effects of stem cells.

ECM/substrate nanotopography and stiffness critically influence numerous developmental, physiological and pathological processes in vivo, and have a profound influence on cell behavior and stem cell fate decision in vitro. It is hypothesized that stem cells can retain nanotopographical information from past culture environments and the nanotopographical memory can influence future fate decision of stem cells. The objective of the proposed research is to test this hypothesis and to delineate the underlying mechanism of nanotopographical memory effects. Three research objectives using human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) as model cells are proposed to study the nanotopographical memory effects: (1) Regulate Yes-associated protein (YAP) intracellular localization by using nanotopography, (2) Validate nanotopographical memory effects, and (3) Delineate the underlying mechanism of nanotopographical memory effects. This research will advance the understanding of cellular mechanotransduction and stem cell plasticity during developmental and pathological processes. It will call attention to unintended nanotopographical memory effects during in vitro culture, which may affect stem cell function and differentiation. This research will contribute to the development of next-generation stem cell culture technologies, and provide insight into the design of new biomaterials and the cell-substrate interfaces of implants and medical devices for regenerative medicine. In addition, a collaborative, cross-disciplinary, learn-through-research system will be established to provide the basic infrastructure to promote nanobiotechnology education in West Virginia.

This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of CBET is co-funded by the Biomaterials Program of the Division of Materials Research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although stem cells have shown significant potentials in regenerative medicine, the realization of the potentials remain limited by current challenges associated with maintenance and directed differentiation of stem cells in cell culture. Conventional cell culture methods using flat, stiff plastic surfaces facilitate cell adhesion and proliferation; however, stem cells lose their regenerative capability quickly. On the other hand, the extracellular matrix (ECM) with which cells interact in living tissues manifests significant nanoscale topographies and exhibits various degrees of stiffness. Matrix/substrate nanotopography and stiffness have a profound influence on cell behaviors and have been designed to maintain the regenerative capability of stem cells or differentiate stem cells towards specific linkages in cell culture. Interestingly, human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) have been shown to possess a stiffness memory from past culture environment and the stiffness memory influenced future stem cell fate decision. Because striking similarities have been observed in cellular responses to substrate nanotopography and stiffness, we hypothesize that stem cells can retain nanotopographical information from past culture environments and the nanotopographical memory can influence future fate decision of stem cells. The objective of this proposal is to test the hypothesis and delineate the underlying mechanism of nanotopographical memory effects.

We have designed a library of nanotopographies having various shapes and dimensions, and investigated how nanotopographical cues affect cell morphology, nuclear deformation, cell tension and intracellular localization of Yes-associated protein (YAP) of multiple cell types including hMSCs, human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) and human lung fibroblasts. The dimensions of nanotopography, in particular height can be used to regulate cell spreading and subsequently downstream cell behaviors, such as proliferation and differentiation of stem cells. Moreover, we have verified that the intracellular localization of YAP in hMSCs can be affected by the nanotopographical cues, and the nanotopography and duration which hMSCs are cultured previously have influence on the intracellular localization of YAP, and consequently proliferation and differentiation in the future. Further we have decoupled nanotopographical cues and adhesive proteins on stiff substrates, which rules out the effects of substrate stiffness. The results show that substrate nanotopographies can deform cells and even nuclei, and thus affect proliferation and differentiation of stem cells. The nanotopographical effects are more significant than the adhesive protein. In addition, the examination of the memory effects of hMSCs on the same nanotopographies with different adhesive protein arrangements suggests that the cell-substrate (adhesive proteins) interface area plays a significant role in the memory effects.

The research underscores the importance of incorporating the ECM characteristics into cell culture technologies, especially for stem cells, and provides general guidance to the design of cell culture surfaces and cell-substrate interfaces of implants. We have established cross-disciplinary collaborations within the West Virginia University (WVU) and with other universities. The resulted instructional materials have been incorporated in the newly developed course Biomedical Nanotechnology, and disseminated in the Children’s Discovery Museum, in the middle school teachers’ workshops in West Virginia and through the internet. The project has also provided research opportunities to three graduate students, four undergraduate students and one high school student. Notably, among the undergraduate students, some coauthor several peer-reviewed journal publications, two undergraduate students have been awarded with the prestigious Goldwater Scholarship, and one has received NSF Graduate Research Fellowship. The education and training in biomedical nanotechnology and the achievements have motivated them to pursue career in engineering and/or medicine – two are at the WVU School of Medicine, and the other two are pursuing a PhD degree in Biomedical Engineering at WVU and Duke University.

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2020
Modified by: Yong Yang
